abstract.p: Elizabeth Morgan letter says essential steps in preventing students from 'falling through the cracks' are a return to orderly classrom atmosphere and reinstitution of discipline (July 7 editorial)

block.p: Re ''Recipe for Weaker Schools'' (editorial, July 7): Having seen three boys through college in the 1950's and 60's and observed local classrooms in the 90's when I read once a week to fourth and fifth graders, I can see two significant things missing today.

''Falling through the cracks'' begins in elementary school. A return to an orderly classroom atmosphere -- calm, quiet, conducive to thinking and learning -- will narrow those cracks considerably. The reinstitution of discipline is a necessary prerequisite. Children want to know limits. They want to know someone cares, which putting limits tells them.

Re ''Recipe for Weaker Schools'' (editorial, July 7): Having seen three boys through college in the 1950's and 60's and observed local classrooms in the 90's when I read once a week to fourth and fifth graders, I can see two significant things missing today.

''Falling through the cracks'' begins in elementary school. A return to an orderly classroom atmosphere -- calm, quiet, conducive to thinking and learning -- will narrow those cracks considerably. The reinstitution of discipline is a necessary prerequisite. Children want to know limits. They want to know someone cares, which putting limits tells them.
Too many children today come from home atmospheres that are too hurried and harried. They might find the classroom to be the only island in life's storm.
ELIZABETH MORGAN South Wellfleet, Mass., July 8, 2000
